# gpuwidget

<!-- markdownlint-disable html -->

![Python 3.7+](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-3.7%2B-brightgreen)
[![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/BMPixel/gpuwidget?label=license&logo=data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](#license)

**`gpuwidget`** is a compact, simple GPU monitor living in your jupyter notebook.


## Quickstart

In your jupyter notebook, run following code in a cell to install **`gpuwidget`** and run it.

```
%pip install git+https://github.com/bmpixel/gpuwidget
import gpuwidget
gpuwidget.live()
```

<p align="center">
  <img width="100%" src="https://cdn-uploads.huggingface.co/production/uploads/62cd3a3691d27e60db0698b0/6-GqmeOUJJefGtG2_0tbE.png" alt="Monitor" style="border-radius: 5px; box-shadow: 10px 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);">
</p>

Then you are all set. The cell will finish in a few seconds, but the monitor will update itself in the background. `gpuwidget` works in jupyter notebook (including VSCode and PyCharm) and Google Colab. 

## Features

- `gpuwidget` manages a thread to update itself. You can click `Stop Tracking` button to stop it or leave it there.
- When not in jupyter notebook, it prints ascii gpu stats from [`gpustat`](https://github.com/wookayin/gpustat).
- Simple and just works.
- Only support NVIDIA Graphics Devices, no AMD support as of now.
